history.content:
Just my two cents...
It'll be challenging to deal with the material in EE16B, which is primarily an EE course, without EE16A (unless you opt to take EECS47D or have significant circuits experience).


With LSCS having to take EE16B from this year, I think it'd be most favorable to take EE16A first rather than a linear algebra class.


-----


I took 110 & 16B this sem: 16B didn't feel like "mostly circuits" by any means (coming from someone with no prior experience in circuits)...

Just my two cents...
It'll be challenging to deal with the material in EE16B, which is primarily an EE course, without EE16A (unless you opt to take EECS47D or have significant circuits experience).

With LSCS having to take EE16B from this year, I think it'd be most favorable to take EE16A first rather than a linear algebra class.

children.subject:
tl;dr: completely different. 

For reference: I took Math 110 with Stankova in Spring 17, and EE16B with Maharbiz and Sahai in Spring 16. 

https://inst.eecs.berkeley.edu/~ee16b/fa17/

Math 110 does not do any of the circuits, controls, SVD/PCA, signals. Basically, Math 110 doesn't cover any of it at all. 

Here is a Math 110 syllabus screenshot.

None of these topics are covered in 16B, or vice versa.

Perhaps a better comparison is EE16A to Math 110. So for reference: I took EE16A in Fa15, and it used to be kind of different back then. But I also TA-ed for the course in Fa17, Su17, and followed the course closely in Sp17. 

Comparison of Math 110 and EE16A:

EE16A covers 1-16, 22, 23, 26. Notably, it does not cover Jordan Canonical Form, Cayley-Hamilton Theorem, Invariant Subspaces, Orthogonal Complements, Adjoints. None of these are required for EE16B though. Also, Math 110 is a proof-based class, so it requires and teaches extremely concrete proof-writing ability.
above anon, can you compare and contrast 16B and 110?
